title: On a building built in 1868
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424032727im_/http:/typophile.com/files/Institute%201868.jpg)

I feel like I’ve seen this elsewhere, but I can’t pin it down. It’s a little similar to fonts that are called Lombardic, but it much less flowing. Can anyone identify it?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Institute 1868.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424032727/http:/typophile.com/files/Institute%201868.jpg) | 15.91 KB |
author: seanos

comments.content:
Lettering on buildings of the era was custom designed by the architect or builder rather than being copied direct from a font. As you note it's similar to Lombardic. The medial spurs and Tuscan terminals make it a true Victorian Frankenfont.  
For digital fonts with some similarity to the Lombardic design you could also check for fonts tagged uncial, medieval, illuminated, Irish, medieval and Celtic.  
I posted a fairly comprehensive set of links to this genre of fonts in [http://typophile.com/node/123144](http://web.archive.org/web/20150424032727/http:/typophile.com/node/123144 "http://typophile.com/node/123144")  
Don

Thanks for the reply Don. I should have realised it wouldn’t be a font as such. I wonder though if they did work from some kind of examples.

I knew there was something incongruous about it all, but as frankenfonts go I don’t find it too appalling. I don’t need to reproduce it. I was just doing some research on the history of the building—some of the descriptions of early picture shows there are quite amusing.

I agree that the letters say Victorian neo-gothic whimsy more than appalling.  
In my opinion, there is nothing wrong with a Frankenfont if the mash-up creates a coherent mood.  
They would work quite well for a dragons/steampunk/Harry Potter milieu.  
Perhaps the letters will inspire a lettering artist or fontmaker to venture a full alphabet.  
Don
